newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity ends up strongly on cold, natgas.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity ends up strongly on cold, natgas.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures surged higher on Tuesday, driven up by heating demand from unseasonably cold weather and strengthening natural gas prices, industry sources said.
"It's cold in the west and it's cold in the east and (natural) gas was certainly higher," said one Houston-based power futures broker.
At least one futures broker called for electricity futures to continue to move up Wednesday, citing fundamentals as pushing prices to new highs.
"We are still in a bullish market," the broker said.
Electricity physicals prices were also said to be higher through much of the U.S., again driven by the cold weather and higher gas prices.
November Palo Verde (PV) ended up $1.21 at a new life-of-contract high of $18.60 per megawatt hour (MWH), while December PV settled $1.00 higher at $18.85 after reaching as high as $18.90 per MWh.
January PV also hit a new contract high of $18.10, then settled 90 cents higher at $18.05 per MWh.
Remaining PV deferreds all closed between 10 and 85 cents higher.
November California-Oregon Border (COB) climbed 80 cents to settle at $19.50 after hitting a new contract high of $19.60, while December COB closed up 80 cents at $20.60 per MWh.
Remaining COB futures were steady to 65 cents higher.
NYMEX said an estimated total of 342 COB and 254 PV contracts traded on Tuesday.
-- Chris Reese, New York Power Desk 212-859-1627
